title: Senate Day 33 of the 2025 Session
summary:
Here is a structured markdown summary of the Georgia Senate Day 33 of the 2025 Session session:

**Overview**
The session featured the introduction of several new bills and resolutions, as well as committee reports on previously introduced legislation. There was discussion of procedural matters and recognitions of visiting students and a congressman.

**Key Actions**
- **HB 111**: No description provided
- **HB 111**: No description provided
- **HR 42**: No description provided
- **SB 1**: No description provided

- **SR 311**: No description provided

**Bills Introduced (First Reading)**

- SB 341: No description provided
- SB 342: Related to retirement
- SB 343: To amend code section related to children and families
- SB 344: Related to state government
- SB 345: Related to state government
- SB 346: Related to state government
- SR 410: Resolution urging action on transportation

- HB 637: Related to state and local government
- HB 732: Related to state and local government 
- HB 734: Related to state and local government

- HB 737: Related to state government

**Notable Moments**
- The Senate President recognized various visiting students and a congressman.
- There was discussion of procedural matters, including dispensing with the reading of the journal.

**Votes**
No recorded votes mentioned.

**Attendance**
No quorum or attendance details provided.

**Adjournment**
The transcript does not indicate when the session adjourned or the date of the next session.

If I could have everyone's attention real quick, please. I can have everyone's attention. We always like to introduce and recognize our congressional delegation, the men and women that come down here and speak to us, the folks who are serving and watching DC on our behalf. We have a very special guest today, good friend of mine. He and I share the same high schools, our own mom and we're both Wilbert Academy graduates, Brian Hells from Peachtree City, Georgia, but as all, and went to college out in California at Pepperdion University. And he's always, ever since graduating from Pepperdion, he's always had a service heart. He's really always poured himself back into public service. He had the opportunity to work in the first Trump administration back in 16 and continued to work alongside President Trump after he left office in 2020 and then back into office in 2024. But opportunity came along that journey, an opportunity for him to run for Congress in his own backyard presented itself and he jumped on that opportunity and he won the decisive race of this past election cycle and he is now representing us and the people of West Georgia and in Congress right now and he's doing a wonderful job. We're glad to have him. He is really, really making some big inroads there in Washington, D.C. and we're loved to hear the update on what's going on with him, but we really appreciate him being here and coming to speak to us this chamber. So please give a warm welcome to Congressman Brian Jack. Thank you. Thank you. Well, thank you very much, Lieutenant Governor, as he mentioned, we're both graduates of Woodward Academy and for those in the gallery, I want you all to know, our Lieutenant Governor was quite the athlete. He was eight years ahead of me at Woodward, but the legend of Bert Jones persisted even when I was there. He went on to be the co-captain of the 2002 SEC Championship winning Georgia Bulldogs football team and I'm incredibly grateful for your support when I launched my campaign for Congress. When you run for Congress, you know who your friends are. He endorsed me on day one and it's something for which I will always be grateful. But before I begin, I would be remiss if I didn't acknowledge and I'd like to also offer a round of applause for someone very special to many of you in the chamber. He is my best friend. He helped run my campaign and I'd like to put on the record, which something that happened just about a month ago. He was nominated by our 47th president to serve as the Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Indian Affairs, Mr. Billy Kirkland. Congratulations. And I just know that if I had mentioned Senator Beech's name just then, the applause of been twice as loud. So I'm very grateful to have time with you all today. I wanted to speak to the Senate because for me, the Georgia Senate has always been the cradle of leadership in Georgia. Mr. Lieutenant Governor, you may know, but the last five governors of our state started their careers here in the state Senate. Among your membership as a former congressman, Mr. Burns, who decided he wanted to get a promotion and ran for the state Senate instead of Congress where I served today and our 39th president, Jimmy Carter, may he rest in peace, started his career in this very chamber. So it's no surprise that many of you are considered the next leaders of Georgia. Many of you have been talked about for different leadership opportunities in just a couple years' time. So I want to take the opportunity to visit with you all today to share with you what I've been up to in these first few months that I've been able to serve the people of Georgia and Congress. I proudly served as Bert noted, Georgia's third congressional district. We've got 15 counties and I overlap with many of you. But my journey with the state Senate started before I ran for Congress. As Lieutenant Governor noted, I worked for President Trump for nine years before I got elected to Congress. I worked in his White House from the very first to very last day of his administration. And therein, I had an opportunity to work with some of y'all. Senator Alvers came to see me a couple times. We worked on some deregulation issues. I got to know my home county state senator, Marty Harbin, incredibly well during that time. And I really enjoyed the opportunity to build a relationship with Senator Beach. President Trump often asked about you and really appreciate the relationship we were all able to build. When I ran for Congress, I had an opportunity to start building a relationship to the state senators whose constituencies now overlap with mine. And I'd like to first acknowledge your rules committee chairman, Mr. Brass. Matt Brass on my first week took me to a breakfast with some county leaders in Calvita County and thereafter he took me to the College of Career Academy, which it really serves as a model for the state and trying to ensure that children coming up that want different types of career paths were able to adapt to the modern workforce. So I'm very grateful for the opportunity to visit with you during that time. Senator Robertson and I probably were together every day toward the stretch. It seemed like every time we were at an event in Harris County or Muscogee County, we were always together. Senator Kennedy kindly opened his doors to me and Macon during my runoff and I'm very grateful for that. And I especially enjoyed the opportunity to build a relationship with Senator Beardin. We talked mostly about sports, not about politics, and I'm incredibly grateful for this opportunity to serve alongside you. But I wanted to today just use as an anecdote, the relationship I have with Senator Marty Harbin, my home county senator, because I think it serves as an opportunity to learn how best we can work together at the state and federal level. After my nomination and I should note Senator Harbin endorsed me in my runoff, incredibly grateful. And I'm very grateful for my nomination. He mentioned to me that there's a company in Griffin, whose headquarters is awesome Petri City in my hometown, and he said they've got a problem with the federal government. It's something you should know about. You're a candidate now, but you should come and learn about it. So Senator Harbin and I went over to a company called Renai, America Corporation, and Griffin, Georgia. Their headquarters is in Petri City, but in Griffin, about three or four years ago, they started manufacturing or started the assemblage of non-condensing tankless water heaters. It's a very specific type of water heater that's built in Griffin, Georgia. And they were concerned, this is last July, they were concerned about a regulation that the Department of Energy was considering that would adjust the efficiency standards and effectively put out a business, the type of water heater that they're manufacturing in Griffin. So Marty and I had a chance to go over, and when the doors open at Renai, America, a former state senator who served with Senator Harbin, Perry McGuire, a wonderful guy who served in this chamber from 93 to 97, welcomed us. He works for Renai now, and he walked us through this issue, and he said, this is something that needs to be on your radar. Fast forward to November. I get elected, President Trump gets elected, and they reach back out. Senator Harbin re-engages that conversation because we got to solve this issue. There's a regulation coming down the pipe. It's a federal reg that could put out a business company that manufactures water heaters and employees three to four hundred of our constituents in this specific area. So I had an opportunity to connect them with some of the Department of Energy people coming in during the transition, but we decided we needed legislative relief. I'm just a freshman congressman, so it takes some time to get your feet wet, but I went to work on it immediately. And there's often times when the President sees change hands, Congress can use this tool called the Congressional Review Act, and it enables us to repeal any regulation that administration enforces within a 60 legislative day window. So it happens that the regulation that came down on Raniah America that would have put it out of business fell within that window just a few weeks ago. So I worked my tail off to make sure we could put this on the legislative calendar, and I'm proud to report and working with the people across my conference in Congress, and likewise, people from Rani. We were able to spend an entire legislative day, or legislative afternoon, I should say, passing a bill in the House to repeal this regulation, we got 11 Democrats to make it a bipartisan solution to a federal regulation that would have put out of business for 100 people in my congressional district. And I am incredibly proud of that, but that relationship started because a member of this body engaged me, someone running for office, or you could engage any of the members that represent you, and said, we've got an issue here at home that you've got to fix, use your tools to fix it for us. And that's exactly the type of effectiveness and efficiency that my entire delegation, everyone that represents you, wants to bring to this specific 119th Congress. I don't want to speak much longer, but I do want to close by saying that that's the nature of what we're trying to do here. We share constituencies, we share the same problems.
